contentList.categoryHeader: All Time Great newsdocumentary Tv Shows

listItems.title: Planet Earth: Blue Planet II
listItems.description: Airing simultaneously on AMC, BBC America, IFC, SundanceTV, and WE tv, the seven-part mini-series takes a look at life in the world's oceans with narration by David Attenborough.

listItems.title: America to Me: Season 1
listItems.description: The 10-part documentary series from Steve James takes a year-long look at Chicago's Oak Park and River Forest High School as students and staff deal with a variety of issues, including race, at one of the most diverse suburban public high schools in the U.S.

listItems.title: The Staircase [2018 Version]: Season 1
listItems.description: Jean-Xavier de Lestrade's 2005 Peabody Award-winning eight-part documentary about the Michael Peterson murder trial comes to Netflix with three new episodes (as well as the two episodes released in 2013 for a grand total of 13 episodes).

listItems.title: Reconstruction: America After the Civil War: Season 1
listItems.description: The four-hour documentary about Reconstruction after the Civil War narrated by Henry Louis Gates Jr features interviews with historians, authors and politicians as well as archival images, documents and recreations of events.

listItems.title: The Zen Diaries of Garry Shandling: Season 1
listItems.description: The two-part documentary by Judd Apatow about the late comedian features interviews with over 40 friends and family, including James L. Brooks, Jim Carrey, Sacha Baron Cohen, David Coulier, Jon Favreau, Jay Leno, Kevin Nealon, Conan O’Brien, Bob Saget, Jerry Seinfeld and Sarah Silverman.

listItems.title: The Vietnam War: Season 1
listItems.description: Ken Burns and Lynn Novick returns with a 10-part, 18-hour documentary miniseries about the war features interviews, archival footage, home movies, photos, and audio clips, as well as original music by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross.

listItems.title: Tig
listItems.description: The documentary follows comedian Tig Notaro over two years as she works on her standup, has a double mastectomy, finds a new romance, and tries to have a baby.

listItems.title: The Roosevelts: An Intimate History: Season 1
listItems.description: The 14-hour documentary series from Ken Burns covers the history and influences the family had from the birth of Theodore Roosevelt in 1858 to the death of Eleanor Roosevelt in 1962.

listItems.title: TIME: The Kalief Browder Story: Season 1
listItems.description: The six-part documentary series produced by Shawn "Jay Z" Carter examines the case of 16-year-old Kalief Browder, who ended up at Riker’s Island prison for three years while awaiting trial after being accused of stealing a backpack (the charge was eventually dropped).

listItems.title: Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck
listItems.description: Brett Morgen's documentary about the Nirvana frontman uses interviews, personal notes, drawings, and recordings to illustrate his life.

listItems.title: Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story: Season 1
listItems.description: The six-part documentary series features home videos, family photos, and news footage about the life of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin, who was killed in 2012 and the rise of the Black Lives Matter movement.

listItems.title: Sing Your Song
listItems.description: The documentary about Harry Belafonte showcases not only his singing and acting career, but also his activism, including his involvement in the civil rights movement and social justice.

listItems.title: Africa: Season 1
listItems.description: Four years in the making, the BBC/Discovery Channel co-production  bring a seven-part mini-series that shows never-before-filmed areas, animals, and their behaviors in Africa.

listItems.title: Six by Sondheim
listItems.description: Newly filmed performances from Darren Criss, Jarvis Cocker, America Ferrera, Jackie Hoffman, Jeremy Jordan, Audra McDonald, Laura Osnes, and Will Swenson, are featured in the documentary directed by James Lapine that focuses on six of Stephen Sondheim's songs: "I’m Still Here" from The Follies, “Something’s Coming” from West Side Story; “Opening Doors” from Merrily We Roll Along; “Send in the Clowns” from A Little Night Music; “Being Alive” from Company; and “Sunday” from Sunday in the Park with George.

listItems.title: Elvis Presley: The Searcher
listItems.description: The two-part three-hour film directed by Thom Zimny takes a look at the pop legend's life up until the 1976 Jungle Room recording sessions with new interviews, never-before seen pictures and video.

listItems.title: The Trade: Season 1
listItems.description: The documentary series from Matthew Heineman focuses on all sides of the drug epidemic, from the drug cartel in Mexico, the police in Ohio and the two families impacted by addiction.

listItems.title: The Curious Case of Curt Flood
listItems.description: HBO Sports brings the story of the St. Louis Cardinals all-star center fielder who fought for free agency after refusing to be traded to the Philadelphia Phillies by suing Major League Baseball in 1969.

listItems.title: Sleepless in America
listItems.description: The documentary directed by John Hoffman of the Public Good Projects talks with experts and everyday people about Americans changing sleep habits over the years and the effects it has on people.

listItems.title: The Italian Americans: Season 1
listItems.description: The four-part documentary series explores the history and impact of Italian Americans on America through archival clips and interviews.

listItems.title: Flint Town: Season 1
listItems.description: For over a year, Directors Drea Cooper and Zackary Canepari along with photojournalist Jessica Dimmock followed the police department as they dealt with crime and budget cuts as the city of Flint welcomed a new mayor and new police chief.

listItems.title: Glory Hounds
listItems.description: Filmed in Afghanistan, the two-hour special profiles four military dogs and their handlers in the war zone as they locate insurgents and dangerous explosives.

listItems.title: Larry Kramer in Love and Anger
listItems.description: Jean Carlomusto's documentary covers the history and the impact of the activist-playwright's work as a writer and organizer with interviews and archival footage.

listItems.title: Marathon: The Patriot's Day Bombing
listItems.description: The Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg documentary made in association with the Boston Globe chronicles the investigations that led to the capture of the Tsarnaev brothers as well as the journey of recovery by three families who survived the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing.

listItems.title: How We Got to Now With Steven Johnson: Season 1
listItems.description: A six installment series starring science writer and professional theorist Steven Johnson which examines at six big ideas and the impact they've made.

listItems.title: If You're Not in the Obit, Eat Breakfast
listItems.description: Carl Reiner talks to longevity expert Dan Buettner, Mel Brooks, Dick Van Dyke, Kirk Douglas, Norman Lear, Jerry Seinfeld, and Betty White about the secrets to living and enjoying life into your 90s.

listItems.title: David Bowie: The Last Five Years
listItems.description: Francis Whately's documentary about David Bowie's final years includes archival clips, music videos, and interviews with friends and collaborators who worked on his final two albums, The Next Day (2013) and Blackstar (2016) as well as the Broadway musical, Lazarus.

listItems.title: Years of Living Dangerously: Season 1
listItems.description: Don Cheadle, Matt Damon, Harrison Ford, Michael C. Hall, and Ian Somerhalder are some of the actors, along with journalists such as Mark Bittman, Thomas Friedman, Chris Hayes, and Lesley Stahl who explore environmental issues in this documentary series executive produced by James Cameron, Jerry Weintraub, Arnold Schwarzenegger, 60 Minutes producers Joel Bach, David Gelberm, and climate expert Daniel Abbasi.

listItems.title: Five Came Back: Season 1
listItems.description: Narrated by Meryl Streep, the three-part documentary based on Mark Harris's 2014 book about Frank Capra, John Ford, John Huston, George Stevens and William Wyler's experiences in and after World War II features interviews from Steven Spielberg, Francis Ford Coppola, Guillermo del Toro, Paul Greengrass and Lawrence Kasdan.

listItems.title: All The President's Men Revisited
listItems.description: The two-hour documentary narrated by Robert Redford includes archival footage and interviews with Bob Woodward, Carl Bernstein, Dustin Hoffman, Ben Stein, David Frost, Tom Brokaw, Rachel Maddow, Joe Scarborough, James Carville, Mary Matalin, and Fred Thompson about the Watergate scandal and the impact of "All the President’s Men," the Oscar-winning 1976 film it inspired.

listItems.title: I Love You, Now Die: The Commonwealth v. Michelle Carter
listItems.description: The two-part documentary directed by Erin Lee Carr examines the 2017 case against Michelle Carter for involuntary manslaughter for the 2014 suicide death of her boyfriend Conrad Roy after hundreds of text messages appear to show she encouraged him to kill himself.

listItems.title: Dirty Money (2018): Season 1
listItems.description: The documentary series from Alex Gibney focuses on cases of fraudulence and misconduct by businesses including Volkswagen, TRUMP Inc., HSBC, payday lenders, and the maple syrup industry.

listItems.title: The Newspaperman: The Life and Times of Ben Bradlee
listItems.description: The life and career of the Washington Post editor Ben Bradley is examined with archival footage, interviews, home movies, and photos in this documentary directed by John Maggio.

listItems.title: The 50 Year Argument
listItems.description: Co-directed by Martin Scorsese and David Tedeschi, the documentary explores the history of The New York Review of Books through  interviews and archival footage.

listItems.title: On Freddie Roach: Season 1
listItems.description: The daily life of boxing trainer Freddie Roach (Manny Pacquiao, Amir Khan, and George St. Pierre are some of his trainees) is the subject of this documentary series produced by Peter Berg.

listItems.title: Witness: Season 1
listItems.description: The HBO docuseries profiles three photojournalists as they work in Juarez, Mexico; South Sudan; Libya; and Rio de Janeiro.

listItems.title: Regarding Susan Sontag
listItems.description: Nancy Kates' documentary explores the life of the late author Susan Sontag, who passed away in 2004 from leukemia, with interviews with her sister, girlfriends, and her writings, read by by Patricia Clarkson.

listItems.title: The Apollo
listItems.description: Roger Ross Williams documentary about New York City's Apollo Theater includes archival footage, behind-the-scenes footage of how the theater runs today as well as interviews with such artists as Patti LaBelle, Pharrell Williams, Smokey Robinson, and Jamie Foxx.

listItems.title: Last Chance U: Season 1
listItems.description: Greg Whiteley's docuseries focuses on the East Mississippi Community College Lions coached by Buddy Stephens as they begin a new season with a 24-game winning streak. Many of the players also have a chance to overcome poor academic performance or behavioral problems to return to Division I football and joining the NFL.

listItems.title: Vietnam in HD: Season 1
listItems.description: New, unseen footage is included in the six-part mini-series about the Vietnam War narrated by Michael C. Hall.

listItems.title: Too Funny To Fail
listItems.description: Josh Greenbaum's documentary about the short-lived comedy The Dana Carvey Show features interviews with Dana Carvey, Steve Carell, Robert Carlock, Stephen Colbert, Jon Glaser, and Robert Smigel.

listItems.title: The Keepers: Season 1
listItems.description: Ryan White's seven-part true crime documentary focuses on the investigations by Abbie Schaub and Gemma Hoskins into the 1969 murder of Sister Cathy Cesnik, a young English teacher at a Catholic high school in Baltimore.

listItems.title: Andre the Giant: Season 1
listItems.description: Jason Hehir's documentary about the life of the WWE star features interviews from  Billy Crystal, Ric Flair, Hulk Hogan, Vince McMahon, Rob Reiner, and Arnold Schwarzenegger.

listItems.title: John McCain: For Whom the Bell Tolls
listItems.description: The Peter Kunhardt documentary about Senator John McCain's life and career features interviews, archival newsreel, home movies and personal photos.

listItems.title: TV Nation: Season 1
listItems.description: Following the success of Roger & Me, documentary filmmaker Michael Moore moved to television for this humorous weekly newsmagazine that found Moore and a rotating group of correspondents (including Janeane Garofalo, Louis Theroux, Karen Duffy, Merrill Markoe, and Jonathan Katz) reporting on topics including corporate crime, politics, organized labor, and more. The show later moved from NBC to Fox for its second season, when it won an Emmy.

listItems.title: Baltimore Rising
listItems.description: The documentary directed by Sonja Sohn follows both sides of the debate after the death of Freddie Gray in 2015 sparks protests in Baltimore.

listItems.title: Cancer: The Emperor of  All Maladies
listItems.description: Based on the Pulitzer Prize-winning book by Siddhartha Mukherjee, the six-hour documentary directed by Barak Goodman (and executive produced by Ken Burns) explores the history of cancer and the latest medical advances with stories of real-life patients.

listItems.title: Soundbreaking: Season 1
listItems.description: The eight-part documentary series look into the history and growth of recording music with interviews with a variety of artists including Beck, Bon Iver, Brian Eno, Elton John, Quincy Jones, Daniel Lanois, Beatles producer George Martin (who also produced the series before his death in March), Paul McCartney, Joni Mitchell, Tom Petty, Q-tip, Bonnie Raitt, and Don Was.

listItems.title: The Diplomat
listItems.description: The documentary about the life and career of Richard C. Holbrooke was directed by his son.

listItems.title: Latino Americans: Season 1
listItems.description: Narrated by Benjamin Bratt, the three-part documentary explores the history and challenges Latinos faced going back more than 500 years to the present time.

listItems.title: Ugly Delicious: Season 1
listItems.description: The documentary series follows chef David Chang and food writer Peter Meehan as they talk about food and culture while visiting restaurants from around the world.

listItems.title: Homegrown: The Counter-Terror Dilemma
listItems.description: Greg Barker's documentary based on based on Peter Bergen's book "United States of Jihad: Investigating America’s Homegrown Terrorists" features interviews with family members of victims and those convicted of terrorist attacks, as well as Andrew Liepman, former Deputy Director of the National Counterterrorism Center and Philip Mudd, former Deputy Director of the FBI's National Security Branch.

listItems.title: The Tenth Inning: Season 1
listItems.description: Ken Burns returns with his four-hour sequel to his Emmy-winning documentary "Baseball." The two-part documentary covers a variety of issues that followed "Baseball's" airing. These include: the strike, the Red Sox's World Series victory, home run records, and steroid scandals.

listItems.title: Manhunt (2013)
listItems.description: The documentary directed by Greg Barker and based on a book by journalist Peter Bergen, explores the nearly 20-year hunt for Osama bin Laden by the CIA with interviews with the analysts and operatives.

listItems.title: The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst: Season 1
listItems.description: The six-part documentary from Andrew Jarecki and Marc Smerling features interviews with New York City real estate heir Robert Durst, who was suspected (and acquitted in one case) of three murders.

listItems.title: Nixon by Nixon: In His Own Words
listItems.description: The documentary from Peter Kunhardt includes archival footage with audio from the tapes Nixon recorded from 1971 to 1973 while in the White House.

listItems.title: Richard Pryor: Omit the Logic
listItems.description: In director Marina Zenovich's documentary, interviews with Lily Tomlin, Bob Newhart, Whoopi Goldberg, Mel Brooks, Jesse Jackson, Quincy Jones as well as rare clips recall the life and work of comedian Richard Pryor.

listItems.title: The Circus: Inside the Greatest Political Show on Earth: Season 1
listItems.description: The political documentary series featuring Bloomberg Politics managing editors Mark Halperin and John Heilemann and campaign strategist Mark McKinnon takes a look behind-the-scenes of the 2016 presidential race.

listItems.title: His Way
listItems.description: Jerry Weintraub, the producer behind such films as Diner, The Karate Kid, and Ocean's Eleven, is profiled in this documentary supplemented with home videos and stories from various celebrities who have worked with him.

listItems.title: TWA Flight 800
listItems.description: The documentary directed by Kristina Borjesson reveals interviews with investigators about the other possibilities on what caused the TWA flight to explode on July 17, 1996, after taking off from JFK International Airport.

listItems.title: Lorena: Season 1
listItems.description: The four-part documentary series executive produced by Jordan Peele about the Lorena and John Wayne Bobbitt case was directed by Joshua Rofé and includes discussion of issues such as the 24-hour news cycle, domestic violence and sexual assault.

listItems.title: In Vogue: The Editor's Eye
listItems.description: Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato direct this documentary about the fashion editors who helped shaped the pages of the 120-year-old fashion magazine.

listItems.title: Wishful Drinking
listItems.description: Carrie Fisher's one-woman show about her family, Star Wars, and being bipolar was filmed from a performance in New Jersey.

listItems.title: Sinatra: All or Nothing at All: Season 1
listItems.description: The documentary directed by Alex Gibney features interviews with his family, co-stars, journalists, as well as a variety of footage of Ol' Blue Eyes performing (including his 1971 "retirement" concert) to illustrate his life and influence on America.

listItems.title: 112 Weddings
listItems.description: The documentary contains footage of weddings director Doug Block filmed over the past two decades with follow-up interviews with the couples about marriage.

listItems.title: History of the Eagles
listItems.description: The two-part documentary directed by Alison Ellwood uses interviews and rare footage to tell the history of the California rock band from its founding in 1971, the breakup in 1980, the band's reunion in 1994, and the recording of 2007's "Long Road Out of Eden."

listItems.title: The Fourth Estate: Season 1
listItems.description: The four-part documentary series directed by Liz Garbus features the editors and reporters at The New York Times as they cover President Trump's first year.

listItems.title: And the Oscar Goes to...
listItems.description: Directed by Robert Epstein and Jeffrey Friedman, the documentary uses clips and interviews to look back at the history and influence of the award show.

listItems.title: The Clinton Affair: Season 1
listItems.description: The six-part documentary from Alex Gibney and Blair Foster takes a look at the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal with new interviews with Ken Starr and Monica Lewinsky.

listItems.title: It's Me, Hilary: The Man Who Drew Eloise
listItems.description: Directed by Matt Wolf, the documentary about the Eloise illustrator Hilary Knight, features interviews with friends, family, writers inspired by his work as well as executive producer and fan Lena Dunham.

listItems.title: Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory
listItems.description: This is the third documentary from Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky about the West Memphis Three. Damien Echols, Jason Baldwin, and Jessie Misskelley were convicted of killing three children in 1993. After several appeals, the three men were released in August 2011 after entering an Alford plea.

listItems.title: Dear Mom, Love Cher
listItems.description: The hour-long documentary explores the life of Cher's mother, Georgia Holt, through interviews with her two daughters and grand children.

listItems.title: Annie: It's the Hard-Knock Life, From Script to Stage
listItems.description: The documentary directed by Joshua Seftel follows the revival production of the Broadway musical including casting, rehearsals, and opening night.

listItems.title: Bobby Kennedy for President
listItems.description: The four-part miniseries directed by Dawn Porter features interviews as well as rare and never-before-seen footage, as it explores the career of the U.S. senator/U.S. Attorney General/presidential candidate.

listItems.title: North America: Season 1
listItems.description: Narrated by Tom Selleck, the seven-part documentary covers a variety of environments and creatures who live on the continent.

listItems.title: Citizen Rose: Season 1
listItems.description: The five-part documentary series follows Rose McGowan as she speaks out in the #MeToo movement and readies the release of her memoir.

listItems.title: Our Nixon
listItems.description: The documentary film by Penny Lane and Brian L. Frye used some of the 500 reels of home movies filmed by Nixon's chief of staff H.R. Haldeman, domestic-affairs advisor John Ehrlichman, and appointments secretary Dwight Chapin, as well as interviews, news footage, and White House tapes.

listItems.title: Inside the American Mob: Season 1
listItems.description: The six-part series explores the Mafia in the U.S. through reenactments, archival footage, and interviews with FBI agents, former mobsters, and informants.

listItems.title: One Strange Rock: Season 1
listItems.description: The 10-part documentary series hosted by Will Smith from Darren Aronofsky and Nutopia features former astronauts talking about what makes Earth so unique to the universe.

listItems.title: America in Color: Season 1
listItems.description: The documentary series narrated by Liev Schreiber features colorized black and white pictures and film footage from the 1920s to the 1960s.

listItems.title: Evil Genius: Season 1
listItems.description: The four-part true crime docuseries from the Duplass brothers looks into a 2003 bank robbery in Pennsylvania by a pizza delivery man with a bomb around his neck who claimed he was forced to commit the crime.

listItems.title: Running with Beto
listItems.description: Directed by David Modigliani, the documentary followed the US Senate campaign by former Texas House Representative Beto O'Rourke in 2018.

listItems.title: Banksy Does New York
listItems.description: Chris Moukarbel's documentary uses interviews with people who seek out his art, videos posted on YouTube and Twitter postings to explore the impact of  the elusive British street artist on New York during his month-long visit in October 2013.

listItems.title: The Address
listItems.description: Ken Burns' follows a group of boys between 11-17-years-old who attend The Greenwood School, a boarding school where many of the children have learning issues such as ADHD or dyslexia, learn the Gettysburg Address.

listItems.title: Addiction
listItems.description: Part of HBO's multi-pronged effort to highlight substance abuse in America, this feature-length documentary is composed of nine short films dealing with the causes, costs, and treatments of drug and alcohol addicition.

listItems.title: The Chair (2014): Season 1
listItems.description: Two first-time directors, Shane Dawson and Anna Martemucci, work on the same script by Dan Schoffer in the documentary series from Project Greenlight's Chris Moore. Ticket sales and digital voting will determine the winner of the $250,0000 prize.

listItems.title: The Inventor: Out for Blood in Silicon Valley
listItems.description: Alex Gibney's documentary about how Elizabeth Holmes and her company Theranos' claims of a compact blood testing machine went from a Silicon Valley start-up worth $9 billion in 2014 to being cited by the SEC for "massive fraud" in 2016.

listItems.title: Lost Songs: The Basement Tapes Continued
listItems.description: The Sam Jones documentary features an interview with Bob Dylan as well as footage of producer T. Bone Burnett, Elvis Costello, Rhiannon Giddens, Taylor Goldsmith, Jim James, and Marcus Mumford creating music based on Dylan's lyrics from his "Basement Tapes" sessions.

listItems.title: Virgin Territory: Season 1
listItems.description: Each week the docu-series will explore the stories of four young people on their decisions to have sex for the first time.

listItems.title: Superheroes: A Never-Ending Battle: Season 1
listItems.description: Narrated by Liev Schreiber, the documentary explores the impact of comic book superheroes over the 75 years history of the genre with interviews with such creators as Stan Lee, Jerry Robinson (co-creator of the Joker), Joe Simon (co-created Captain America with Jack Kirby), and Todd McFarlane as well as actors Adam West and Lynda Carter.

listItems.title: Being Serena: Season 1
listItems.description: The five-part docuseries follows tennis champion Serena Williams as she begins her journey into motherhood.

listItems.title: Ethel: Season 1
listItems.description: Rory Kennedy chronicles the life of her mother, Ethel Kennedy through family pictures, home movies, news footage, and interviews.

listItems.title: There's Something Wrong With Aunt Diane
listItems.description: The Liz Garbus documentary looks into the 2009 tragic accident of Diane Schuler, who drove the wrong way on New York's Taconic State Parkway before crashing into another SUV, killing herself and seven others.

listItems.title: The Devil Next Door: Season 1
listItems.description: A Cleveland grandfather is accused of being a Nazi camp guard known as "Ivan the Terrible"

listItems.title: Mankind: The Story of All of Us: Season 1
listItems.description: Narrated by Josh Brolin, the 12-hour documentary miniseries traces the beginnings of humanity from hunter-gathers to the modern civilizations we have created.

listItems.title: Brooklyn DA: Season 1
listItems.description: The six-part documentary series follows the work of the Brooklyn (Kings County) district attorney's office.

listItems.title: Breakthrough: Season 1
listItems.description: The six-part series features focuses on the latest scientific research on such topics as pandemics, aging, robotics, the brain, energy and water. Peter Berg, Brett Ratner and Adrien Brody, Paul Giamatti, Ron Howard, Akiva Goldsman and Jason Bateman, and Angela Bassett are some of the directors and actors involved.

listItems.title: The Bomb: Season 1
listItems.description: The documentary explores the history and impact of nuclear weapons with interviews with scientists, historians, pilots, weapons designers, former Secretary of State George Shultz, and former Defense Secretary William Perry.

listItems.title: Leah Remini: Scientology and the Aftermath: Season 1
listItems.description: In the docuseries Leah Remini talks about Scientology and interviews former Scientologists about their experiences.

listItems.title: The Spymasters - CIA in the Crosshairs
listItems.description: Narrated by Mandy Patinkin, the documentary focuses on the controversial methods used by the agency after Sept. 11 with interviews with 12 former CIA directors, several operatives, and critics of the CIA.

listItems.title: Requiem for the Dead: American Spring 2014
listItems.description: Shari Cookson and Nick Doob's documentary uses news footage and social media postings to tell the stories of the lives of those killed in different shootings in the Spring of 2014 and the impact on their families.
